About Today: Procession of the Venerable and Life-giving Cross. Commemoration of the SS. Seven Machabee Brothers, Martyrs, their names being Abim, Antonin, Gurius, Eliazar, Evseon, Alim, Marcell, and their Mother, Solomonia, and their Master, Eleazar, martyred 173 B.C. during the reign of Antiochus, son of Seleucus.
Remarks: Feast of the Procession of the Holy Cross. Lesser Blessing of Water. Beginning of the Dormition Fast. 8/1 - 8/14.

About Today: Translation of the Holy Relics of St. Stephen, the first Martyr and Archdeacon from Jerusalem to Constantinople during the reign of the Emperor Constantine the Great A.D. 312. (Other Feast of this Saint is on the 27th day of December.) — St. Stephen, Priest-Martyr, Pope of Rome, and others with him martyred A.D. 260, during the reign of Valerian and Gallienus, Emperors. Tradition alleges that he was beheaded while seated in his chair before the Altar in the Catacombs.

Our venerable fathers, Isaacius, Dalmatius and Faustus. Isaacius died A.D. 368 in the reign of Valens, Emperor. He had predicted the death of Valens, the Arian, going into battle. This prediction fulfilled, Dalmatius and Faustus died in the reign of Theodosius the Great, Emperor (379-395).
Remarks: Aliturgical day (without Divine Liturgy) may be observed.

About Today: SS. Seven Youth of Ephesus, Martyrs, their names being: Maximilian, Dionisius, Amblichus, Martin, Antonin, John and Marcell. (Confer October 22.) — St. Eudokia, Venerable-Martyr.
Remarks: Aliturgical day (without Divine Liturgy) may be observed.

About Today: St. Eusignius, Martyr, an old soldier in the army of Constantine Chlorus, Emperor, who at the age of one hundred and ten years, refused to sacrifice to idols on command of Julian the Apostate, Emperor. He was scourged and beheaded as a Christian at Antioch in Syria A.D. 362.

The Transfiguration of our Lord, God and Saviour, Jesus Christ. By this manifestation of His Divine Glory, Jesus Who has just foretold His Passion to the Apostles, strengthened their Faith and prepared them for His sufferings and death.

St. Domitius, Venerable-Martyr. Julian the Apostate, Emperor, irritated it is alleged by the reproaches Domitius ventured to address to him, had him stoned to death A.D. 362. — St. Pulcheria was the daughter of the Eastern Emperor Arcadius. On the death of her brother, Emperor Theodosius II, a fallen away Catholic, she became Empress, and ruled wisely and well. She died A.D. 453. The Ecumenical Council of Chalcedon salutes Pulcheria as "Guardian of the Faith, maker of peace, pious, orthodox and a second St. Helen."
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: St. Emilian, Confessor, Bishop of Cyzicus, fearlessly denounced the Iconoclasts. He was brought before the Emperor Leo the Armenian, subjected to many indignities, and died in exile A.D. 820. — SS. Eleutherius and Leonidas, Martyrs.

St. Matthias, Apostle. Some writers suppose him to have preached the Gospel in Judea and later in Ethiopia, and to have met his death by crucifixion. Others assert that he was stoned to death by the Jews in Jerusalem.
Remarks: Feast of the Holy Apostle Matthias, Epistle, Acts 1:12-17,21-26; Gospel Luke 9:1-6.

About Today: St. Lawrence, Archdeacon-Martyr, one of the most famous martyrs of Rome. He was a Deacon of the Pope St. Sixtus II. This holy deacon was tortured and in the end was roasted alive on a gridiron A.D. 258, under Emperor Valerian.

St. Euplus, Archdeacon-Martyr, endured death A.D. 304 during the reign of the Emperor Diocletian. He was put on the rack and bidden to worship Apollo, Mars and Aesculapius. He replied that he adored only the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit.
SS. Photius and Anicetus, Martyrs, suffered death A.D. 288 during the reign of Diocletian, Emperor.
Remarks: Poor Clares. Our Venerable Mother Clare.

About Today: Our venerable father, Maximus, Confessor, was a Greek of noble birth, at first attached to the Court of the Emperor Heracluis, but later retired to the monastery of Chrysopolis (Scutari). For championing the Faith against the Monothelites, St. Maximus was seized in Rome, and taken as prisoner to Constantinople, and for his steadfastness, his right hand was cut off and his tongue torn out. He died of his wounds in prison A.D. 662.
Remarks: Final Day of the feast of the Dormition.

Day Name: Translation of the Relics of Theodosius of the Cave—Venerable
About Today: St. Micah, Prophet, one of the Twelve Minor Prophets, of the stock of Ephrem, and contemporary of the Prophet Isaiah. He continued to prophesy for fifty-four years into the first decades of the eighth century B.C. — Translation of the Relics of our venerable father, Theodosius, Hegumen-Abbot of Cave, which took place A.D. 1091, in the presence of the Great Russian Prince, Vsevolod, and his Hegumen, John. This Translation was made from his grave in the Cave to the church of the Mother of God which St. Theodosius had built. (Confer May 3.)

Dormition (Assumption) of The Theotokos. It is considered to be our Lady's greatest Feast. The commemoration of her death and the Assumption of her body and soul into heaven was the occasion of special devotion in very early times. In Ephesus it was observed even in the first century. In A.D. 1950 Pope Pius XII defined and promulgated the Assumption of the Theotokos to be a dogma of the Church.

Day Name: 12TH SUNDAY AFTER PENTECOST|Translation of the Icon of Our Lord
About Today: Translation of the miraculously formed Icon of Our Lord, Jesus Christ, from Edessa to Constantinople, called "Veronica's Veil," A.D. 950 — St. Diomidius, Martyr, endured death A.D. 288 during the reign of the Emperor Diocletian.
Remarks: Feast of the Translation of the Icon of our Lord, Epistle Colossians 1:12-18 or 2 Corinthians 3:4-11; Gospel, Luke 9:51-56,10:22-24.

About Today: St. Myron, Martyr, who was seized by the imperial officers of Decius, Emperor, tortured and executed for the Faith A.D. 250 in Cyzicus on the Sea of Marmora. — SS. Paul and Juliana, his sister, Martyrs in Palestine. Both patiently endured savage torture before being beheaded with other Martyrs under Julian the Apostate.
SS. Florus and Laurus, Martyrs. They were twin brothers and stone-cutters by trade, who for the Faith were put to death by drowning in a well A.D. 320 under the power of Licinius.

St. Andrew, a Tribune in the Greek army and with is 2,593 soldiers, Martyrs, who were massacred for the Faith on Mt. Taurus in Silicia A.D. 300 in the reign of Maximian, Emperor. — SS. Timothy, Agapius and Thecla, Martyrs. Timothy was burned at the stake; Agapius and Thecla were thrown to the wild beasts in the Amphitheatre, in the reign of the Emperor Diocletian, A.D. 306.
St. Samuel, Prophet, in the 11th century B.C. — St. Stephen the First, Apostolic King of Hungary, died A.D. 1038. His Right Hand is miraculously kept intact.

St. Thaddeus, Apostle, one of the 70 Apostles, descendant of a Jewish Family in the city of Edessa, and was a disciple of St. John the Baptist-Precursor. He died in peace at Beiruth, in Palestine. — SS. Bassa and her children, Theogonius, Agapius, and Pista (Fidelis), Martyrs, suffered death under one of Diocletian's colleagues about A.D. 304.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: St. Agathonicus and with him: Zoticus, Theoprepius (which means "Grace of God"), Acindynus and Severianus, Martyrs, suffered death A.D. 304 during the reign of the Emperor Maximian.

St. Lupus, Martyr, died A.D. 278. — St. Iraeneus, Priest-Martyr, Bishop of Lugdun in Gallia, martyred probably A.D. 210 by Septimus Severus, Emperor. — Our holy father, Callinicus, Patriarch of Constantinople.
Remarks: Final Day of the Feast of the Dormition.

About Today: St. Eutyches, Bishop-Martyr, disciple of John the Theologian, Apostle and Evangelist.

Day Name: Return of the Relics of Bartholomew—Apostle
About Today: Return of the Relics of Bartholomew, Apostle. (Confer June 11.) — St. Titus, Apostle. Titus was the favoured disciple of St. Paul and was his successor as the first Bishop of the Island of Crete. He died full of merits about the close of the first century.
SS. Adrian and Natalie, Martyrs, endured death A.D. 304 during the reign of Maximian, Emperor.
Our venerable father, Poeman, an Egyptian by birth, flourished in the period of the Ecumenical Council at Ephesus A.D. 431 in the reign of Theodosius the Younger, Emperor.

Our venerable father, Moses, an African Negro of Abyssinia, styled the "Ethiopian Hermit." — Our holy father, Augustine, Confessor and Bishop of Hippo in Africa. He is one of the greatest doctors of the Western Rite Church. He died A.D. 430. — St. Anna, daughter of Phanuel. (See 3rd day of February).
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: The Beheading of St. John, Glorious Prophet, Precursor and Baptist. He was beheaded by Herod Antipas, at the instigation of Herodias.
Remarks: Beheading of St. John the Baptist. By tradition, strict abstinence from meat and dairy products.

About Today: Our holy father, Alexander, John and Paul the New, Patriarchs of Constantinople.
Remarks: Final Day of the Feast of the Beheading of St. John the Baptist.

Day Name: Deposition of the Cincture of the Theotokos
About Today: Deposition of the Venerable Cincture of the Theotokos, translated from the See of Zela to Constantinople, A.D. 908.
